channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Leaving Hospital, U.S. Envoy Vows to Stay ‘Open and Friendly’ in South Korea
item.description: Ambassador Mark W. Lippert, being discharged five days after a knife attack, said his belief in the two countries’ bond had only been strengthened.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Helicopters Crash in Argentina; 10 Are Killed
item.description: Eight of the victims were from France, including three prominent athletes, and they were on their way to work on a reality television show.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: From left, Andrew Wong/Reuters; Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Derrick Ceyrac/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: From left, three prominent French athletes who died: Alexis Vastine, Camille Muffat and Florence Arthaud.

item.title: Helicopters Crash in Argentina; 10 Are Killed
item.description: Eight of the victims were from France, including three prominent athletes, and they were on their way to work on a reality television show.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: From left, Andrew Wong/Reuters; Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Derrick Ceyrac/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: From left, three prominent French athletes who died: Alexis Vastine, Camille Muffat and Florence Arthaud.

item.title: Armenian Leaders Establish Rights Award to Commemorate Centenary of Genocide
item.description: The award is part of an effort to go beyond remembering the 1.5 million people who died, emphasizing how survivors led successful lives.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: China: Dalai Lama Supporter Burns Herself in Protest
item.description: A Tibetan woman who supported the exiled Dalai Lama set herself ablaze and died in a Tibetan part of southwest China, advocacy organizations abroad said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: International Criminal Court Seeks U.N. Action on Sudan
item.description: The court has long sought the extradition of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir on genocide and other charges in the Darfur conflict.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Peace Corps Suspends Program in Jordan
item.description: Turmoil and terrorism in neighboring countries is cited as the reason for the temporary removal of 37 volunteers from Jordan.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: U.S. Offers $5 Million for News on Ex-F.B.I. Agent
item.description: The United States announced Monday that it had increased to $5 million its reward for information that could lead to the safe return of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: G.O.P. Senators Write to Iran About Nuclear Deal
item.description: The letter, signed by 47 Republican senators, warns Iran that a nuclear agreement may not last without congressional approval, angering the president and Iran.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: World Briefing: France: 4 Held on Suspicion of Links to Paris Attackers
item.description: Four people, including a police officer, have been taken into custody over suspected links to January’s terrorist attacks in Paris, officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Order Freezes Assets of 7 Officials in Venezuela
item.description: The White House said the sanctioned government officials were implicated in human rights violations in Venezuela.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing: British Lawmaker Is Named Next Humanitarian Chief
item.description: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced Monday that a British lawmaker, Stephen O’Brien, will be the next United Nations humanitarian chief.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: North Korean Diplomat, Found With Gold Stash, Is Expelled
item.description: Bangladeshi customs officers said Son Young-nam, the first secretary of the North Korean Embassy in Dhaka, had tried to smuggle 60 pounds of gold into the country on Friday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Memo From France: Extramarital Dating Site Unsettles the Land of Discreet Affairs
item.description: A provocative advertisement for a dating website geared to married women looking for affairs has spawned a backlash and a national debate.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A photo provided by Gleeden shows an ad from the company’s latest campaign on a Paris bus. Infidelity “destroys the social fabric of France,” a spokeswoman for a Catholic family group said.

item.title: Chechen Links Boris Nemtsov Killing to Charlie Hebdo Cartoons
item.description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov suggested that the Kremlin critic may have been killed for defending cartoons that mocked the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov of Chechnya praised a man accused of killing a Kremlin critic.

item.title: Neighbors of Nigeria Take On Boko Haram
item.description: Troops from Chad and Niger attacked Boko Haram militants in neighboring Nigeria, two days after the Islamist terror group killed scores in bombings there.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: HSBC Again Comes Under Fire From British Lawmakers
item.description: Bank executives are accused of incompetence in a hearing on tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: JENNY ANDERSON

item.title: U.N. Presses North Korea to Account for Abductions
item.description: A human rights investigator is seeking international action to resolve the fates of foreigners who disappeared.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Panel Seeks More Time for Gaza War-Crimes Inquiry
item.description: A United Nations panel due to present findings soon on last year’s fighting has requested a postponement.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Russia’s Well for Corporate Bailouts Appears to Be Running Dry
item.description: A fund for subsidies, opened for corporate appeals last year, might not have enough to cover all the requests for aid it has received.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
